ControlledConcept.gml:description: A surface that separates geologic units [adapted from page 137 of Jackson, 1997]. Very general concept representing any kind of surface separating two geologic units, including primary boundaries such as depositional contacts, all kinds of unconformities, intrusive contacts, and gradational contacts, as well as faults that separate geologic units. Note that usage of geologic unit here is per NADM C1 2004, denoting a body of material. Lines on geologic maps may also delineate featured defined geomorphically-- craters, terraces, shorelines, scarps that are not inherently geologic unit boundaries in this sense. Source: NADM C1 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:contact
ControlledConcept.name: Contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A non-faulted contact separating bodies of material in the earth that have different lithologic character or geologic history. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:lithogenetic_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Lithogenetic contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Lithogenetic contact at which a sedimentary or volcanic rock has been deposited on (or against) another rock body. The relationship between the older underlying rocks and younger overlying rocks is unknown or not specfied. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:depositional_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Depositional contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A contact separating two geological units in which the layers are formed one above the other in order by regular, uninterrupted deposition under the same general conditions. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:conformable_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Conformable contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A contact separating two geological units in which the younger unit succeeds the older after a substantial hiatus in deposition. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:unconformable_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Unconformable contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An unconformable contact between two geological units in which the older, underlying rocks dip at an angle different from the younger, overlying strata, usually in which younger sediments rest upon the eroded surface of tilted or folded older rocks. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:angular_unconformable_contact
ControlledConcept.name: angular unconformable contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An unconformable contact between two geological units in which the bedding of the older, underlying unit is parallel to the bedding of the younger, overlying unit, but in which the contact between the two units is marked by an irregular or uneven surface of appreciable relief. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:disconformable_contact
ControlledConcept.name: disconformable contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An unconformable contact between an underlying, older nonstratified geological unit (usually intrusive igneous rocks or metamorphics) and an overlying, younger stratified geological unit. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:nonconformable_contact
ControlledConcept.name: nonconformable contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An unconformable contact between two geological units in which the bedding of the older, underlying unit is parallel to the bedding of the younger, overlying unit, in which the contact between the two units is planar, and may be coincident with a bedding plane. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:paraconformable_contact
ControlledConcept.name: paraconformable contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An unconformity in which onlapping strata are truncated against a steep topographic scarp. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:buttress_unconformity
ControlledConcept.name: Buttress unconformity

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An intrusive contact between a younger igneous rock and an older, pre-existing geological unit into which it has been intruded. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:igneous_intrusive_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Igneous intrusive contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An intrusive contact between a sedimentary rock unit and plastic sediment (e.g., clay, chalk, salt, gypsum, etc.), forced upward into it from underlying sediment Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:sedimentary_intrusive_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Sedimentary intrusive contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Lithogenetic contact separating rocks that have different lithologic properties related to metamorphism, metasomatism, alteration, or mineralization. Generally separates metamorphic rock bodies, but may separate metamorphosed (broadly speaking) and non-metamorphosed rock. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:metamorphic_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Metamorphic contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A metamorphic contact separating rocks that have undergone metamorphism of a particular facies from those that have undergone metamorphism of another facies. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:metamorphic_facies_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Metamorphic facies contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A metamorphic contact separating rocks that have undergone metasomatism of a particular facies from those that have undergone metasomatism of another facies. Metasomatism is distinguished from metamorphism by significant changes in bulk chemistry of the affected rock. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:metasomatic_facies_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Metasomatic facies contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A metasomatic facies contact separating rocks that have undergone alteration of a particular facies from those that have undergone metasomatism of another facies. Alteration is a kind of metasomatism that does not introduce economically important minerals. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:alteration_facies_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Alteration facies contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A metasomatic facies contact separating rocks which have been mineralised and contain a particular mineral assemblage from those which contain a different assemblage. Mineralization is a kind of metasomatism that introduces ecomomically important minerals. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:mineralisation_assemblage_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Mineralisation assemblage contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A lithogenetic contact separating bodies of material differentiated based on lithologic properties related to weathering. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:weathering_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Weathering contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A lithogenetic contact separating essentially coeval sedimentary material bodies distinguished by characteristics reflecting different physical or chemical processes active at the time of deposition of the sediment. Source: base on Nichols, Gary, 1999, Sedimentology and stratigraphy, Blackwell, p. 62-63.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:sedimentary_facies_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Sedimentary facies contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A lithogenetic contact separating lithologically distinct phases of a single intrusive body. Does not denote nature of contact (intrusive or gradation). Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:igneous_phase_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Igneous phase contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A lithogenetic bundary separating rock masses that have different deformation structure, e.g. sheared rock against non sheared rock, brecciated rock against non-brecciated rock. Use for contact of impact- or volcanic-explosive- related shattering. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:deformation_zone_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Deformation zone contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A contact separating two bodies of material across which one body has slid past the other. Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:faulted_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Faulted contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A contact separating bodies of material in the earth that have different geophysical properties. Use for boundaries that are detected by geophysical sensor techniques as opposed to direct lithologic observation. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:geophysical_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Geophysical contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A geophysical contact separating bodies of material defined based on the intensity emitted of radiant energy of some sort (e.g. gamma rays). Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:radiometric_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Radiometric contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A geophysical contact separating bodies of material distinguished based on properties related to magnetic fields. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:magnetic_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Magnetic contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A magnetic contact between bodies of material with different magnetization, direction or intensity. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:magnetization_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Magnetization contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A magentic contact between bodies of material with different polarity of remnant magnetization, e.g. between sections of ocean floor with different polarity. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:magnetic_polarity_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Magnetic polarity contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A magnetic contact between bodies of material with different magnetic susceptibility. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:magnetic_susceptiblity_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Magnetic susceptiblity contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A geophysical contact separating bodies of material defined based on their seismic character. Seismic character is based on transmission of vibrations (seismic waves) through a rock body, and relates to the velocity of transmission, and the nature of reflection, refraction, or transformation of seismic waves by inhomogeneities in the rock body. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:seismic_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Seismic contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A geophysical contact separating bodies of material with differnent densities, generally determined through measurement and modelling of gravity variations. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:density_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Density contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A geophysical contact between bodies of material with different electrical conductivity Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:conductivity_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Conductivity contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A contact between regions characterised by their geological history or by similar structural, petrographic or stratigraphic features Source: Neuendorf, K.K.E, Mehl, J.P. & Jackson, J.A. (eds), 2005. Glossary of geology, 5th Edition. American Geological Institute, Alexandria, 779 p.
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:geologic_province_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Geologic province contact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A contact between bodies of material having different ages of origin. Source: FGDC
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ContactType:200811:chronostratigraphic_zone_contact
ControlledConcept.name: Chronostratigraphic-zone contact
